fi.grimripper.loww.tiles

Class Hex

  • java.lang.Object
    • fi.grimripper.loww.tiles.Tile
      • fi.grimripper.loww.tiles.Hex

  • public class Hex
extends Tile
    Represents a single hexagon, or hex, in a tile grid. Each hex has up to six neighbors, at least three even for hexes in the grid's corners. Each hex has the same width and height as every other hex. Their locations, of course, vary. This class implements some calculations, and a drawing algorithm for hexes.
    Author:
    Marko Tuominen
    See Also:
    FilledRowHexGrid

      • getHexSides

        public static Direction[] getHexSides()
        Gets an array with the six directions of a hex's sides. The directions are in clockwise order, starting from northeast.
        Returns:
        directions of a hex's sides

      • getHexPoints

        public static Direction[] getHexPoints()
        Gets an array with the six directions of a hex's points. They're in clockwise order, starting from north.
        Returns:
        directions of a hex's points

      • getPoint

        public Point getPoint(Direction corner)
        Gets coordinates for one of this hex's points. Hexes don't have points to the west and east.
        Specified by:
        getPoint in class Tile
        Parameters:
        corner - specifies which corner is requested
        Returns:
        a Point with corner's coordinates, or null for an invalid corner direction

        Specified by:

        Returns:
        a Point with the tile's center point coordinates

      • containsCoords

        public Hex containsCoords(double x,
                 double y)
        Tests if this hex contains a pair of coordinates. A hex doesn't have neighbors to the north or to the south, so returns northeast/southeast if the x-coordinate is the same as this hex's center's, but the coordinates are not in this hex.
        Specified by:
        containsCoords in class Tile
        Parameters:
        x - the x-coordinate
        y - the y-coordinate
        Returns:
        this tile if the coordinates are inside it, or the closest neighbor (can be null if there isn't a neighbor in the correct direction)

        Returns:
